abstract.text: No overview available.
Using the queried items, apply a transform to each creating
a query of new items. Transform may return nil to skip item.
If items do not yet exist in the item hierarchy “attach()”
can be used to add them.
Protocol to support any wrapper that can
do simple chaining (return self) or chaining
of items that remain the same T type.
Recursively remove all quadrants from the grid(s)
including any sub-guides, views or layers they may contain.
Specify “leaveSubHierarchy:true” to only remove the
quadrants and leave any sub-guides/view/layers intact.
Add a debug overlay or grid overlay.
See also “debug” operator which does the same.
Optionally provide overlay/grid color or for
non-grid types an overlay title.
Debug colors use brightness tinting so should
generally be dark or light (depending on your
needs). See also ColorDerivable “lighter”
or “darker” to adjust color if necessary.
Accent the control(s) using an implicit animation.
Animation effectively uses a “linear” animation curve.
It’s not necessary to wrap this method in an animation block.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated, once for turning accent
on, and then again for turning accent off.
To change the duration of each segment of the animation,
override the method “controlStateAnimationDuration” on
the control(s) – e.g. to provide an overall time (accent
on and off) of 1.0, then return 0.5.
Optionally provide async delay in seconds.
For view-based controls see also “accentedViews()”
which animates view hierarchy changes (but not sub-layer
changes) using non-linear or custom timing curve.
Present the queried Presentable item(s) and
automatically dismiss them after a delay
with optional dismiss speed, presentation
speed/delay, and completion handler.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
If a completion handler and a dismiss action (via onDismiss {})
have been specified, both will be run after dismissal
with the completion handler being run last.
Create a new item based on reducing queried items (starting from
a seed item) and return a new Query with that item.
See also several variations of “empty()” to use as the initial item.
QuerySelectionInterface represents any wrapper (Query,
Mutator or AutoLayout) that can select/deselect queried items.
Given a query of items apply a flatMap transform that
returns arrays of items that become combined into
a single array or Query of items.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin integer
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent grid query,
passing a quadrant within which items will reside
Call this method anywhere you have a parent query.
Example: childrenQuery.in(parentQuery, quadrant:“A1:C4”)
Shift the first item to become the base,
creating an empty query preserving original type.
Unshift the base to become the only result item
(keeping the base). Optionally pass itemToReference
to bump the first item to become the reference.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent item (view/layer/etc)
Example: childrenQuery.in(parent)
Traverse this query’s items and another query’s items
in parallel, returning the original query that has
as many items as the shortest query of the two.
Treat the current query as a subtype – for example to get
specialized functionality that would not otherwise be exposed
to a more general type.
Beware: this will remove items where the type cannot be succesfully
cast. e.g. Query
containing 2 views, a UIView and a UIButton
using treat(as:UIControl.self) will “lose” the UIView (which is
a UIControl) and return 1 view, the UIButton (which
a UIControl).
Export this query of CaptionDelegates to a query
of the delegate’s associated Captions.
Save off via inout variable the frame of
a single item or the union’d frame of
mutiple items.
Create an empty query.
Previous state is maintained including
the query’s base item, any references,
debug paramaters, etc
Shift the first item to become the base,
while keeping “only” the original item
and removing others.
Create a new query which is the difference of two queries.
“Difference”: items that are not shared in either query.
The opposite of “intersect”. Passed query should be the
same type or subtype of the original (output) type.
Attach this query of child item(s) to their parent grid(s),
passing a quadrant within which items will reside.
Call this method from a build { block } passing the $0 builder.
Example: parent.build { children.in($0, quadrant:“A1:C4”) }
Attach the current query of items to it’s query reference preserving
the relative position in the new parent item - via originNormalized().
This operator is not animatable. However, to simulate animation of this change,
set the new parent item as a reference item, animate the change (e.g.
originToReference, centering, etc), then in the animation completion handler
run attachToReference() to complete the transition to the new hierarchy.
This method support attaching across divergent types (e.g. attaching
a Button to a View), which is different than attach() which does
support this.
Using the queried items, apply a transform to each creating
a query of new items. If these items do not yet exist in the
item hierarchy attach() can be used to add them.
Update the items with the related model objects
either initially or whenever the model changes.
Provided model array is applied in parallel to items.
Optionally provide whether the visual appearance
should be updated always, conditionally or never.
Wrap the current queried item(s) in a Layer, moving those items
into the layer, resizing the layer to fit the items (items will
keep original relative positions) and add layer to provided
(layer, view or guide) or for a single item, it’s actual parent
layer/backing-layer/guide, and for multiple items the common parent
layer/backing-layer/guide of those items.
This method essentially inserts a layer in the hierarchy between
the parent and a set of other items.
NOTE: The origin of the inserted layer will be adjusted automatically
so that the item(s) maintain their optical position.
However, if a parent is provided which is in another coordinate space
than the item(s), then you will have to adjust the layer origin manually.
To maintain the same vertical position, the embedded layer uses
the zPosition of the first item.
Provide
to add additional padding to the layer, otherwise
the new layer will fit exactly to contain the sub items.
Pass
to use a custom embed type.
Pass
for the embed’s identifier.
Pass
for the embed’s ordinal.
Passing any of these will cause the attachment of the embedded
item(s) to be reusable.
IMPORTANT: when embedding multiple reusable items be sure to use
the same set of items (in the same order) if calling this again
so that they are ordinalized correctly wrt reusable attachment.
If embedding in a Live layout you will need to pass builder option
on attachment of the item(s) and ensure the embed is
reusable so that the hierarchy will not be redundantly constructed.
Example:
Enable the custom controls.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Pass .noUpdate to prevent the update or .requireUpdate
to ensure the update is performed regardless.
By default this triggers a control state update only
if the state passed is different than the existing state.
Use .noUpdate if you will handle the update yourself
without conforming to the protocols.
Associate dependent sibling item(s) of the current query
in parallel with the master item(s) of another query.
Detaching the master item(s) will detach the
dependent sibling item(s).
Interleave the items in the current query with another
so that they are in alternating order starting with
the first query, with default to include excess items
from the longer query.
Attach this query of child item(s) to their parent(s).
Call this method from a build { block } passing the $0 builder.
Example: parent.build { children.in($0) }
Filter this query for disabled controls
QueryInterface provides the common interface to
queried items via Query, Mutator and Autolayout wrappers.
Get the first ancestor(s) of specified type and ordinal.
Respects hybrid hierarchies (parent guides, etc).
This returns a parent for each item in the query
removing duplicates.
To get the common parent of all items, use QueryFactory
instead: e.g. query.with?.parent/literalParent, etc
Perform mutations with options or parameters within
a closure without affecting the outer query.
Prepare the item(s) for presentation.
This is the state
presentation
(typically when the item is not visible to the user).
It is also used in the defult dismiss() to
reverse the process.
NOTE: prepare() is called automatically by the
system when the item is attached to the hierarchy.
If calling it manually, you must ensure it is safe
to call multiple times.
Present the queried Presentable item(s) and
automatically dismiss them after a delay
with optional dismiss speed, presentation
speed/delay, and completion handler.
Provide a non-optional data model to be
used in presentation.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
If a completion handler and a dismiss action (via onDismiss {})
have been specified, both will be run after dismissal
with the completion handler being run last.
Toggle the enabled state of the queried control items
after async delay.
If the items conform to ControlStateUpdatable this will
trigger callbacks to update the visual state of the control.
Create a new query based on the current one and another one
without duplicates. Passed query should be the same type or
subtype of the original (output) type.
Wrap the current queried item(s) in a View, moving those items
into the view, resizing the view to fit the items (items will
keep original relative positions) and add view to provided
view/guide or for a single item, it’s actual parent view/guide/
containing view, and for multiple items the common parent view/guide
of those items.
This method essentially inserts a view in the hierarchy between
the parent and a set of other items.
NOTE: The origin of the inserted view will be adjusted automatically
so that the item(s) maintain their optical position.
However, if a parent is provided which is in another coordinate space
than the item(s), then you will have to adjust the view origin manually.
To maintain the same vertical position, the embedded view uses
the zPosition of the first item.
Provide
to add additional padding to the view, otherwise
the new view will fit exactly to contain the sub items.
Pass
to use a custom embed type.
Pass
for the embed’s identifier.
Pass
for the embed’s ordinal.
Passing any of these will cause the attachment of the embedded
item(s) to be reusable.
IMPORTANT: when embedding multiple reusable items be sure to use
the same set of items (in the same order) if calling this again
so that they are ordinalized correctly wrt reusable attachment.
If embedding in a Live layout you will need to pass builder option
on attachment of the item(s) and ensure the embed is
reusable so that the hierarchy will not be redundantly constructed.
Example:
Show relative positions over top of queried item(s).
For example: topLeading, center, etc.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent item (view/layer/etc)
Example: childrenQuery.in(parent)
Get the
cousin item(s) of
type,
parent/sibling type and cousin string
Update existing remainder layer(s) by reconstructing them in relation
to the current definable area layer(s) and optionally update the
remainder’s content items using the trailing closure.
Enter debug mode.
This provides both visual typographic debugging
and console debugging.
See debugTypographic() for more options.
Query from the current items.
Returns nil if current query has no items.
Example: myQuery.with { $0.buttons }
Export the current query of views to their backing layers
Display the entire layout guide hierarchy in the console.
Provide option “includeAll” to see C3 internal types
and other private types in the output.

inlineContent.text: This works on debug builds only. It’s used for debugging only.

abstract.text: Create new views or layers using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
layer(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be CALayer (child layers of the parent layers).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new layers.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Export this query of dependent item(s) to it’s
sibling master item(s).
Filter  views that are above/below/before/after some layout item
within the current view’s coordinate space.
Example: query.views.positioned(.below, .guide(headerGuide), clears:true)
See also Query.ordered(by:Edge)
Get the parent Guide(s) of the current guide(s).
Focus the custom controls.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Pass .noUpdate to prevent the update or .requireUpdate
to ensure the update is performed regardless.
By default this triggers a control state update only
if the state passed is different than the existing state.
Use .noUpdate if you will handle the update yourself
without conforming to the protocols.
Show relative “quadrantals” over top of queried item(s).
For example: A1, C3, etc
Attach an action that will be fired on item dismissal.
Get the parent UIView(s) of the current view(s).
See also Query.parent() which supports getting
– e.g. query.parent(Guide.self)
Turn off console debugging.
Create a new query with just one item of any type
while maintaining the original base.
Get the
cousin item(s) of
type,
parent/sibling type and cousin string
Treat the current query’s base as some other type/subtype.
Beware: this may remove the base altogether if the type
cannot be successfully cast.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin string
Create a new query of parent Padder view(s) of the
current queried view(s). This may reduce the query to
less or no results if none of the views have padders.
Wrap the current queried item(s) in a View, moving those items
into the view, resizing the view to fit the items (items will
keep original relative positions) and add view to provided
view/guide or for a single item, it’s actual parent view/guide/
containing view, and for multiple items the common parent view/guide
of those items.
This method essentially inserts a view in the hierarchy between
the parent and a set of other items.
NOTE: The origin of the inserted view will be adjusted automatically
so that the item(s) maintain their optical position.
However, if a parent is provided which is in another coordinate space
than the item(s), then you will have to adjust the view origin manually.
To maintain the same vertical position, the embedded view uses
the zPosition of the first item.
Provide
to add additional padding to the view, otherwise
the new view will fit exactly to contain the sub items.
This method will prevent implicit layer animations from occuring.
Pass
to use a custom embed type.
Pass
for the embed’s identifier.
Pass
for the embed’s ordinal.
Passing any of these will cause the attachment of the embedded
item(s) to be reusable.
IMPORTANT: when embedding multiple reusable items be sure to use
the same set of items (in the same order) if calling this again
so that they are ordinalized correctly wrt reusable attachment.
If embedding in a Live layout you will need to pass builder option
on attachment of the item(s) and ensure the embed is
reusable so that the hierarchy will not be redundantly constructed.
Example:
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus optional cousin
Unregister a cell class of a given re-use identifier to prevent
the table view from using it to create new tables view cells.
Alternatively, register a different cell class to take it’s place.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin
Assign table delegate to table(s)
Filter this query for visible items only.
Checks for items that are visible in any way
checking for visibility beyond just alpha and
“isHidden” property, including the existence
of color, borders, shape properties, custom
layer addons and recursive subitem visibility.
See also “visible” for a simpler version
that only includes isHidden and alpha.
Shift the first item to become the base,
creating an empty query of the specified type.
Attach the current query of items to
or
. In the case of attaching to base
this will remove the base from items
See also “build/in” API for adding items to hierarchy.
Unlike attachToParentQuery this method does not
using cloning so child items will be used as-is.
Update a single item with a related model object
either initially or whenever the model changes.
To apply a single data model to multiple items
use the specialized update(withOne:) method.
Optionally provide whether the visual appearance
should be updated always, conditionally or never.
Enter debug mode with
This provides both visual typographic debugging
and console debugging.
See debugTypographic() for more options.
Query from the current items (with options).
Returns nil if current query has no items.
Example: myQuery.with(.nonrecursive) { $0.buttons }
Export the current query of layers to their owning views
if the layers have owning views (sublayers would not).
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus optional cousin
Turn on visual typographic debugging.
Provide
(dark or light), whether to
include typographic
information and
which typographic
to include
(e.g. .firstXHeight, etc).
The view(s) flexible remainder area(s) expressed via
a closure containing the UI description of that area.
The parent used to add hierarchy into (aka $0) is
a RemainderView (UIView). Example:
Register a cell class to be used by table view(s)
in creating new table view cells.
Reuse identifier is based on class name (or provided).
Shift all items so that the first item becomes the base
and other items the result (without the first item)
Filter this query for items with non-clear color.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent grid,
passing a quadrant within which items will reside.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent item (view/layer/etc)
Example: childrenQuery.in(parent, quadrant:“A1:C4”)
Detach queried items from their super items and return those
items in the query (which you can either use by reattaching,
or just let the query go out of scope and the items to deallocate).
NOTE: Detaching views will also remove associated constraints.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent grid,
passing a quadrant within which items will reside.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent item (view/layer/etc)
Example: childrenQuery.in(parent, quadrant:“A1:C4”)
Create new views, layers or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
guide(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be UIView (child views of the parent guides).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new guides.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Focus the custom controls after async delay.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Assign table data source to table(s)
Results of the query
Given a query with snapshottable view(s)
capture a reference to the snapshottable view(s)
to be stored and snapshotted the next time
a snapshot wrapper is used with the same copy
identifier. For example:
Save the current item(s) animatable state. This state can
later be restored via
Toggle the selected state of the queried control items.
If the items conform to ControlStateUpdatable this will
trigger callbacks to update the visual state of the control.
Pass update:false to prevent the update.
The protocol composition that views, layers, guides and nodes
conform to on all generic wrappers, such as Query, Mutator and others.
Given item(s) that are UIControls, CustomControls
or ControlStateDependents, update their visual appearance
according to their current control state.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Normally, it’s not necessary to call this method
because in most cases setting a control state via
any of the state API (enabled(), etc) will trigger updates.
Toggle the enabled state of the queried control items.
If the items conform to ControlStateUpdatable this will
trigger callbacks to update the visual state of the control.
Pass update:false to prevent the update.
Update existing remainder view(s) by reconstructing them in relation
to the current definable area view(s) and optionally update the
remainder’s content items using the trailing closure.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin string
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent query.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent query.
Example: childrenQuery.in(parentQuery)
Filter this query for selected controls
Treat the current query’s base and item type to match
a given Builder closure type. Beware: this may remove
the base and/or items altogether if the current query
cannot be successfully cast to the builder type.
Update debug label. This method is TBD.
Select items of a certain type
alias to treat(as)
Create new items using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to this parent item(s).
Create new views, layers or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
guide(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be CALayer (child layers of the parent guides owning views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new layers.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Filter this query for highlighted controls
Select the custom controls after async delay.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Query from the current items
and return the first item found.
Example: myQuery.withFirstOf { $0.buttons }
See also “with(max)” to return specific number of items.
Remove items from the current query by returning
the query or subset of that query from a closure.
Example detaching and removing items from a query:
views.remove { $0.last.detach() }
Wrap multiple queried items in separate views, moving those items
into their respective views, resizing the views to fit each item
and add the new views to provided
view/guide or the parent
view/guide of those items. For single items, just use embedView(),
or for multiple items if you want all items within a single view.
This method essentially inserts separate views in the hierarchy
between the parent and each item.
NOTE: The origin of the inserted views will be adjusted automatically
so that the item(s) maintain their optical position.
However, if a parent is provided which is in another coordinate space
than the item(s), then you will have to adjust the view origins manually.
To maintain the same vertical position, the embedded views use
the zPosition of the first item.
Provide
to add additional padding to the views, otherwise
the new views will fit exactly to contain each item.
Pass
to use a custom embed type.
Pass
for the embed’s identifier.
Passing any of these will cause the attachment of the embedded
item(s) to be reusable.
IMPORTANT: when embedding multiple reusable items be sure to use
the same set of items (in the same order) if calling this again
so that they are ordinalized correctly wrt reusable attachment.
If embedding in a Live layout you will need to pass builder option
on attachment of the item(s) and ensure the embed is
reusable so that the hierarchy will not be redundantly constructed.
Example:
Wrap multiple queried items (layers) in separate layers, moving those items
into their respective layers, resizing the layers to fit each item
and add the new layers to provided
layer/view/guide or the parent
layer/guide of those items. For single items, just use embedLayer(),
or for multiple items if you want all items within a single layer.
This method essentially inserts separate layers in the hierarchy
between the parent and each item.
NOTE: The origin of the inserted layers will be adjusted automatically
so that the item(s) maintain their optical position.
However, if a parent is provided which is in another coordinate space
than the item(s), then you will have to adjust the layer origins manually.
To maintain the same vertical position, the embedded layers use
the zPosition of the first item.
Provide
to add additional padding to the layers, otherwise
the new layers will fit exactly to contain each item.
Pass
to use a custom embed type.
Pass
for the embed’s identifier.
Passing any of these will cause the attachment of the embedded
item(s) to be reusable.
IMPORTANT: when embedding multiple reusable items be sure to use
the same set of items (in the same order) if calling this again
so that they are ordinalized correctly wrt reusable attachment.
If embedding in a Live layout you will need to pass builder option
on attachment of the item(s) and ensure the embed is
reusable so that the hierarchy will not be redundantly constructed.
Example:
Query from the current items specifying the
maximum number of items the query should return.
Returns nil if current query has no items.
Example: myQuery.with(3) { $0.buttons }
Create a new query with items of a type
while maintaining the original base.
Create new nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
node(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be SKNode (child nodes of the parent query).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new nodes.
Attach this query of child item(s) to their parent(s).
Call this method from a build { block } passing the $0 builder.
Example: parent.build { children.in($0) }
Turn on visual and console debugging with
existing debug configuration.
Update existing remainder guide(s) by reconstructing them in relation
to the current definable area guide(s) and optionally update the
remainder’s content items using the trailing closure.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin string
Get the
cousin item(s) of
type,
parent/sibling type and cousin integer
Create a new query of parent LayerPadder(s) of the
current queried layers(s). This may reduce the query to
less or no results if none of the layers have padders.
Enable interaction between Backdrop(s) and a delegate.
For example, if tapping the backdrop(s) means something.
Add action to be executed when Backdrop is tapped on.
SPECIAL BEHAVIOR: If a CancelButton exists within the
hierarchy of the current item(s) and that button has
it’s own attached action, that action will also be
run when the backdrop is tapped (assuming Backdrop
dismissal has not been disabled).
NOTE: it’s not necessary to dismiss the item(s) from
within the closure, dismissal is automatic – unless
disabled via “backdropTapDoesNotDismiss()”.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin
Create a new query where two queries intersect.
Passed query should be the same type or
subtype of the original (output) type.
Treat these layers upcast to their most general type, CALayer.
Create an empty query of a specific type.
Previous state is maintained including
the query’s base item, any references,
debug paramaters, etc
Present the queried Presentable item(s)
with optional duration, delay or
completion handler that the “present()”
implementation can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Select the custom controls.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Pass .noUpdate to prevent the update or .requireUpdate
to ensure the update is performed regardless.
By default this triggers a control state update only
if the state passed is different than the existing state.
Use .noUpdate if you will handle the update yourself
without conforming to the protocols.
Additional specialized operators that cannot be represented
with the other QueryInterface protocols because of diverse
generic return types.
Get the the first ancestor(s) of specified type and ordinal.
Respects hybrid hierarchies (parent guides, etc).
This returns a parent for each item in the query
removing duplicates.
To get the common parent of all items, use QueryFactory
instead: e.g. query.with?.parent/literalParent, etc.
Act on found item(s) via closure without interfering
with the outer chain.
Dismiss the queried Presentable item(s)
with optional duration, delay and completion
handler that the “present()” implementation
can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed this query
of each item to take action on.
If a completion handler and a dismiss action (via onDismiss {})
have been specified, both will be run after dismissal
with the completion handler being run last.
Get the
sibling item(s) of the current type.
See other “sibling” methods for more options.
Export the current query of layers to their containing views.
In case the query items are backing layers, this
will return their owning views. In case of sub-layers
(of the backing layer), this will return the containing views.
Get the parent CALayer(s) of the current layer(s).
See also Query.parent() which supports getting
– e.g. query.parent(Guide.self)
Traverse this query’s items and another query’s items in
parallel, with zipper returning a new query for each.
For base item, will resolve to the base item of the last
iteration OR by passing reevaluateBase:true to the common
super item of all items.
Create new views, layers or guides using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
guide(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be Guide (child guides of the parent guide).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new guides.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Present the queried Presentable item(s) and
automatically dismiss them after a delay
with optional dismiss speed, presentation
speed/delay, and completion handler.
Provide a non-optional array of data models
(applied in parallel to items) to be used
in presentation.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
If a completion handler and a dismiss action (via onDismiss {})
have been specified, both will be run after dismissal
with the completion handler being run last.
Detach (remove) all sub items of the queried items
from their super items
Any
that can work with references.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent query.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent query.
Example: childrenQuery.in(parentQuery)
Export this query of Guide(s) to their owning view(s).
Traverse items in overlapping pairs
and reduce (“prune”) those pairs to single items
returning a new Query of items, or return
nil for items to exclude the pair altogether.
Specialize the custom controls (aka “special” state).
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
In the context of themes, “special” state overrides
all other states.
Pass .noUpdate to prevent the update or .requireUpdate
to ensure the update is performed regardless.
By default this triggers a control state update only
if the state passed is different than the existing state.
Use .noUpdate if you will handle the update yourself
without conforming to the protocols.
Traverse this query’s items and an arbitrary array of
things in parrallel with a trailing closure that is
passed an item and a thing. The resulting query length
will be the shorter of the two.
Unregister a cell class to prevent the table view from using
it to create new tables view cells. Alternatively, register
a different cell class to take it’s place.
Reuse identifier is based on class name.
See also unregister(cellReuseIdentifier:) that takes custom reuse identifier.
Treat these views upcast to their most general type, UIView.
Prevent the item(s) from dismissing on tapping Backdrop.
(Default behavior is to dismiss on tapping Backdrop
and run any provided action closures.)
Save the current item’s animatable state to an external
array of AnimatableState objects. This state can
later be restored via Mutator.restore(state:).
Save the current Query to a variable,
the current items onto that external variable (i.e. as
opposed to just replacing the external variable). This
is useful in loops where it’s necessary to gather results
or when it’s necessary to perform an action on multiple items.
e.g. var spacers = Q
.empty()
..   Spacer().in($0)….accumulate(&spacers)
IMPORTANT: Use “var” for empty query otherwise this will not work.
Supports saving diverse subtypes of a common type.
e.g. var layers = Q
.empty() - Shape
..   Circle().in($0)….accumulate(&layers) - subtype
The base of the last accumulated query becomes the base
of the saved query (which in context is usually the same).
Param “preserveOrder” ensures new items are appended
to the end of the current query, thus maintaining order
– this is the default behavior.
Get the
cousin item(s) of
type,
parent/sibling type and cousin
Treat these nodes upcast to their most general type, SKNode.
Display the entire layer hierarchy in the console.
Provide option “includeAll” to see C3 internal types
and other private types in the output.

inlineContent.text: This works on debug builds only. It’s used for debugging only.

abstract.text: Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type wil be the generic type specified (e.g. Label.self).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new items.
Attach this query of child item(s) to their parent grid(s),
passing a quadrant within which items will reside.
Call this method from a build { block } passing the $0 builder.
Example: parent.build { children.in($0, quadrant:“A1:C4”) }
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes)
get the containing (or owning) view(s).
ItemQueryInterface represents any wrapper that can
access the underlying items and act on them via closure
in a way that does not alter the original query.
Query, Mutator and AutoLayout all support this,
as does AnyMutator.
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes)
get the containing (or owning) view(s), of a specified type.
Highlight the custom controls after async delay.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Toggle the selected state of the queried control items
after async delay.
If the items conform to ControlStateUpdatable this will
trigger callbacks to update the visual state of the control.
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin string
Turn on console debugging with options.
The guide(s) flexible remainder area(s) expressed via
a closure containing the UI description of that area.
The parent used to add hierarchy into (aka $0) is
a RemainderGuide (UILayoutGuide). Example:
Get the
cousin item(s) of
type,
parent/sibling type and optional cousin
Save the current item’s animatable state to an
AnimatableStates object. This state can later
be restored via Mutator.restore(state:).
NOTE: AnimatableStates is a class. If you prefer to
use value types only, use the other save() method
which takes an array of AnimatableState structs.
Add a debug label with optional title.
Filter this query for text fields with text
Specialize the custom controls after async delay.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
In the context of themes, “special” state overrides
all other states.
Filter this query for text fields without text
Associate dependent sibling item(s) with a master item.
Detaching the master item will detach the dependent siblings.
Embed this query of layer(s) in a SwiftUI hierarchy
and use the closure to apply SwiftUI modifiers.
Example:
Present the queried Presentable item(s)
with a provided data model (applied to
all item(s)) and optional duration, delay or
completion handler that the “present()”
implementation can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Update the item(s) with the related model object
either initially or whenever the model changes.
Provided model object is applied to all items.
If the intention is to apply a single model object
to a single item, use the regular update(with:)
method instead.
To apply multiple models in parallel to multiple items
use the update(with:) method which takes an array.
Optionally provide whether the visual appearance
should be updated always, conditionally or never.
Wrap part of the chain in debug (with options) ensuring that
unneeded console output is avoided for the rest of the chain.
Regardless, visual debugging enabled here will remain enabled.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent item (view/layer/etc)
Example: childrenQuery.in(parent)
Get the
cousin item(s) using a path
of three types: the ancestor/parent of the current
item, to the sibling of the ancestor/parent, and
finally to the descendent/cousin of the sibling,
plus cousin integer
A “cousin” is the parent/ancestor’s sibling’s children.
Optionally provide
to select
a specific parent’s sibling (non-inclusive of parent).
Pass
to ignore parent guide relationships
in determining what is a “cousin”.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent query.
Call this method anywhere you have a parent query.
Example: childrenQuery.in(parentQuery)
Filter this query for items with non-clear color
or matching provided color.
Embed this query of view(s) in a SwiftUI hierarchy
and use the closure to apply SwiftUI modifiers.
Example:
Filter this query for enabled controls
Traverse this query’s items and another query’s items in
parallel, returning a new query with items returned from zipper.
Keeps original base.
Turn off visual and console debugging.
If you want to isolate the console debugging by
focussing on a limited set of operators in the chain
(i.e. so as not to overwhelm the console) but
to have visual debugging, then use the
operator that takes a closure and wrap the operators
in the closure. This will isolate the console output to
the enclosed operators
preserve visual debugging.
Turn on visual and console debugging, with options.
Wrap multiple queried items in separate views, moving those items
into their respective views, resizing the views to fit each item
and add the new views to provided
view/guide or the parent
view/guide of those items. For single items, just use embedView(),
or for multiple items if you want all items within a single view.
This method essentially inserts separate views in the hierarchy
between the parent and each item.
NOTE: The origin of the inserted views will be adjusted automatically
so that the item(s) maintain their optical position.
However, if a parent is provided which is in another coordinate space
than the item(s), then you will have to adjust the view origins manually.
To maintain the same vertical position, the embedded views use
the zPosition of the first item.
Provide
to add additional padding to the views, otherwise
the new views will fit exactly to contain each item.
This method will prevent implicit layer animations from occuring.
Pass
to use a custom embed type.
Pass
for the embed’s identifier.
Passing any of these will cause the attachment of the embedded
item(s) to be reusable.
IMPORTANT: when embedding multiple reusable items be sure to use
the same set of items (in the same order) if calling this again
so that they are ordinalized correctly wrt reusable attachment.
If embedding in a Live layout you will need to pass builder option
on attachment of the item(s) and ensure the embed is
reusable so that the hierarchy will not be redundantly constructed.
Example:
All C3 wrappers are DebugConfigurable.
Export this query of master item(s) to it’s
sibling dependent item(s).
Highlight the custom controls.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Pass .noUpdate to prevent the update or .requireUpdate
to ensure the update is performed regardless.
By default this triggers a control state update only
if the state passed is different than the existing state.
Use .noUpdate if you will handle the update yourself
without conforming to the protocols.
Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be CALayer (child layers of the parent views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new layers.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Create a new query with views removed from the other query.
Passed query should be the same type or subtype of the
original (output) type.
Filter this query for visible items only.
This uses both “hidden” and “alpha” properties
to determine visibility.
See also “visibleInAnyWay” for a more
exacting version of visibility.
Attach this query of child item(s) to a parent grid query,
passing a quadrant within which items will reside
Call this method anywhere you have a parent query.
Example: childrenQuery.in(parentQuery, quadrant:“A1:C4”)
Protocol to wrap the ability to create/save wrappers
separate from their declarative chains.
Export the current query of views to their backing layers.
Present the queried Presentable item(s)
with provided data model(s) applied in
parallel to item(s).
Optionally provide duration, delay or
completion handler that the “present()”
implementation can choose to work with.
Completion handler is passed a query
of each item to take action on.
Filter this query for selected controls
Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be Guide (child guides of the parent views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to the new guides.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Attach this query of child item(s) to their parent(s).
Call this method from a build { block } passing the $0 builder.
Example: parent.build { children.in($0) }
Create new views, layers, guides or nodes using a trailing closure.
These (child) items can be added to the (parent)
view(s) of the current query via in($0).
The return type will be UIView (child views of the parent views).
Follow this call by further mutations applicable to child views.
Alternatively, to control the return type, use the generic method.
Turn on visual and console debugging.
See console to turn on only console debugging.
Given a query with snapshottable view(s)
capture a snapshot of the snapshottable view(s)
to be stored and snapshotted the next time
a snapshot wrapper is used with the same copy
identifier. For example:
The layer(s) flexible remainder area(s) expressed via
a closure containing the UI description of that area.
The parent used to add hierarchy into (aka $0) is
a RemainderLayer (CALayer). Example:
Get the
sibling item(s) or ancestor’s sibling item(s)
of the current query type that exists
the current item(s)
in the hierarchy.
This method respects parent guide relationships in determining what
is a “sibling”, unless
is set to false.
See other “previous” methods for more options.
Remove debug label.
Select items of a certain type and act
on them in a closure without affecting
the outer query.
Conditional method to turn console debugging on
if there is an existing (passed) debug wrapper (with options).
Display the entire view hierarchy in the console.
Provide option “includeAll” to see C3 internal types
and other private types in the output.

inlineContent.text: This works on debug builds only. It’s used for debugging only.

abstract.text: Shift the first item to become the base,
while retaining the original items as
the query result, including the first.
Turn on console debugging.
Enable the custom controls after async delay.
The items should conform to ControlStateUpdatable or
ControlStateDelegate so that the visual state
of the control can be updated.
Get the parent SKNode(s) of the current nodes(s).
Filter this query for invisible items.
This uses both “hidden” and “alpha” properties
to determine visibility.
See also “completelyInvisible” for a more
exact version of invisibility.
Traverse items in pairs, e.g. 1/2, 3/4 etc
and reduce (“prune”) those pairs to single items
returning a new Query of items, or return
nil for items to exclude the pair altogether.
This will not include last item if there is
an odd number of items.
Filter this query for invisible items.
Excludes items that are visible in any way
checking for visibility beyond just alpha and
“isHidden” property, including the existence
of color, borders, shape properties, custom
layer addons and recursive subitem visibility.
See also “invisible” for a simpler version
based solely on isHidden and alpha.
Add debug rulers to queried item(s)
with optional style (grid, coordinates
or centers) and shade (dark or light).
Use “flip” to flip one or both axes.
Support conditional inline logic in chainable interfaces.
Export this query of Guide(s) to their guide layer(s).
Clean up any state saved by C3
This would normally be called in the view controller’s deinit.
